user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_finish:
```c
void
MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_finish (void)
{
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME
  if (_MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV != mono_clock_service)
  {
    mach_port_deallocate (mach_task_self (),
                          mono_clock_service);
    mono_clock_service = _MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME
  if (_MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV != mono_clock_service)
  {
    mach_port_deallocate (mach_task_self (),
                          mono_clock_service);
    mono_clock_service = _MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code as written: when HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME is defined and mono_clock_service can differ from _MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV at runtime, the if-condition can be true and the body executed. A specific scenario that WOULD violate Rule 2.1 is if mono_clock_service is a compile-time constant (or macro) equal to _MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV so the condition is provably always false (or if HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME is never defined so the block is permanently excluded from all builds)—in that case the code inside the if would be unreachable and would violate Rule 2.1.
